<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_daemon_info:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN const union MHD_DaemonInfo *
MHD_get_daemon_info (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                     enum MHD_DaemonInfoType info_type,
                     ...)
{
  if (NULL == daemon)
    return NULL;

  mhd_assert ((0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) || \
              (NULL != daemon->worker_pool) || \
              (MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));
  mhd_assert (((0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) &&
               (NULL == daemon->worker_pool)) || \
              (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));

  switch (info_type)
  {
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_MAC_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_LISTEN_FD:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd.listen_fd = daemon->listen_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_EPOLL_FD:
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd.epoll_fd = daemon->epoll_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd;
#else  /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
    return NULL;
#endif /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_CURRENT_CONNECTIONS:
    if (! MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon))
      MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    else if (daemon->worker_pool)
    {
      unsigned int i;
      /* Collect the connection information stored in the workers. */
      daemon->connections = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < daemon->worker_pool_size; i++)
      {
        /* FIXME: next line is thread-safe only if read is atomic. */
        daemon->connections += daemon->worker_pool[i].connections;
      }
    }
#endif
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections.num_connections
      = daemon->connections;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_FLAGS:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags.flags = daemon->options;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_BIND_PORT:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port.port = daemon->port;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port;
  default:
    return NULL;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (! MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon))
      MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment itself. The call to MHD_cleanup_connections(daemon) is not a recursive call unless MHD_cleanup_connections (or any function it calls) calls MHD_get_daemon_info either directly or through an intermediate call chain. A concrete violation scenario would be: MHD_get_daemon_info -> MHD_cleanup_connections -> some_func -> MHD_get_daemon_info (direct or indirect call back), which would breach MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2. Inspect the implementation of MHD_cleanup_connections and its callees (or run call‑graph analysis) to ensure no path leads back to MHD_get_daemon_info.
